newsitem.title: USA: BOXING-MORRISON RETURNING TO RING NEXT MONTH.
newsitem.headline: BOXING-MORRISON RETURNING TO RING NEXT MONTH.

text.p: HIV-infected former heavyweight contender Tommy Morrison will return to the ring next month in Tokyo in a bout to raise money for children stricken with AIDS.

Morrison, who retired eight months ago after testing positive for the virus that causes AIDS, is fighting undistinguished boxer Anthony Cooks on the undercard of the George Foreman-Crawford Grimsley card on November 3.
Morrison said he hopes to raise $500,000 to benefit the Knockout AIDS Foundation.
"The main objective has always been to finance the Foundation and this is the most effective, fast way to do it," Morrison said of his decision to return.

"I don't really miss boxing," said Morrison. "I'm doing this strictly for the foundation, that is my sole purpose. I made a lot of promises to these kids and I want to live up to my end of the bargain and boxing is what I do best."

Morrison, 45-3-1, has not fought since being stopped by Briton Lennox Lewis in the sixth round 12 months ago, but is not worried about his fitness for the scheduled 10-round bout against Cooks, 9-5-0.

"I always work out and I've been been in the gym about three weeks," said Morrison, who expects to weigh near his usual 225 pounds (102 kg) for the fight. "I've been doing a little sparring for two weeks so everything is going fine."
Though he has plans to fight just this one time, Morrison would not rule out more fights under the right circumstances.
"If the opportunity presents itself that would be beneficial to the foundation we will do it," Morrison said.
Morrison said the concerns of him infecting others in the ring are unfounded.
"I feel very comfortable with it, I don't think there is anything wrong with somebody fighting someone with HIV positive as long as the other person knows," said the 27-year-old Morrison.
"The risks are much higher to get a brain contusion than HIV in the ring. Once they see it happen (the fight), it won't be frowned upon so much."
Nevertheless, Morrison has agreed to certain rule changes for the fight.
"If I suffer an uncontrollable cut, I will automatically stop the fight and whoever is ahead on the scorecards wins the fight," Morrison said. "It has to be a very bad cut."
